input:

43:09 Caption: The game is pretty dull as Bayern Munich are just passing the ball from player to player. Nothing lasts forever, though, and they finally make a mistake, allowing the opposition to pick up the ball.

45:02 Caption: Philipp Lahm (Bayern Munich) shoots from the edge of the penalty area. The ball travels towards the target, but Fabiano easily deals with the threat.

47:05 Caption: There will be nothing more to see in the first half. The whistle blowing of Martin Atkinson has ended it.
47:59 Caption: There was certainly plenty of action during that opening 45 minutes. Bayern Munich dominated the opening period and easily created the most chances. The home side are keeping possession of the ball with some short passes, while the visitors are waiting to open up their defence and hit them swiftly on the break.

Great display from the home side, you have to say that they were the better side today. It was obvious that the hosts tried to outplay their opponents with some passing football, while the visitors focused on counter-attacking play.
    

    #######TASK 
    Provide a factually correct and detailed textual description of the game compiled from the information presented above from different sources, in more than 1000 words.
            "Cap:": represents the captions published in the online portal usually within 30 seconds of the event.
            "E:" represents events recorded exactly after the event happened.
    Don't mention sources of information like commentators or captions, write as if you saw them live.
summary:
It was a night to remember at the Allianz Arena as Bayern Munich delivered a resounding performance to secure a 6-1 victory over FC Porto. The match was a showcase of Bayern's tactical prowess and clinical finishing, leaving FC Porto with little room to maneuver.

The game kicked off with Bayern Munich taking the initiative from the get-go. The first notable action occurred only 16 seconds into the match as the ball went out of play, quickly setting the tone for a high-paced and intense game. FC Porto's initial possession, marked by a series of throw-ins, was soon disrupted by a foul on Bayern Munich's part at the 45-second mark. Following an indirect free-kick by Bayern, the game fell into a rhythm of ball exchanges and fouls.

Bayern Munich's offensive efforts began to yield results in the ninth minute when Robert Lewandowski came close to breaking the deadlock. Lewandowski's rebound shot smashed against the left post, signaling Bayern's attacking intent. Despite this near miss, Bayern Munich didn't have to wait long to find the back of the net. In the 14th minute, Thiago Alcantara capitalized on a beautiful lofted cross by Juan Bernat to head the ball past the goalkeeper into the left side of the goal, marking a well-deserved 1-0 lead for the home side.

FC Porto's response to going behind was marred by a series of fouls and disjointed play. Their frustration was evident when Ricardo Quaresma made a reckless challenge that earned Bayern a free-kick. However, they often failed to convert their opportunities into meaningful attacks, as illustrated by overhit set-pieces that went out of play.

Bayern continued to apply pressure, and their efforts were rewarded again in the 22nd minute. From a well-executed corner by Thiago Alcantara, Holger Badstuber rose highest to head the ball towards the six-yard box. Jerome Boateng was on hand to glance a header into the net, doubling Bayern's advantage to 2-0.

The home side's dominance was further underlined in the 27th minute. A quick series of passes between Thomas Muller and Philipp Lahm orchestrated a move that culminated in a precise chip into the area. Lewandowski didn't miss this time, nodding the ball deftly into the back of the net to make it 3-0. Bayern's fluid passing and synchronized team play frequently left FC Porto chasing shadows.

With the score heavily tilted in Bayern’s favor, FC Porto's frustrations boiled over into more physical play. Hector Herrera received a yellow card in the 34th minute for a rough tackle, highlighting the mounting pressure on the visitors. Moments after the booking, Bayern extended their lead to 4-0 through a somewhat fortuitous goal by Thomas Muller. His shot from distance took a deflection off a defender, wrong-footing the goalkeeper and finding the net.

FC Porto's first significant chance came in the 37th minute when Jackson Martinez tried to create space, but Bayern's defense remained resolute. Minutes later, Martinez himself was booked for a foul, another indicator of FC Porto's struggle to cope with Bayern's relentless pressure.

Just before halftime, Robert Lewandowski took center stage once again. After superb coordination with Thomas Muller, Lewandowski slotted a low, accurate shot into the bottom left corner, pushing the scoreline to an almost unassailable 5-0. The first half concluded with Bayern Munich firmly in control, both on the scoreboard and in the flow of play.

As the second half commenced, FC Porto made a couple of substitutions in an attempt to salvage some pride from the game. Ruben Neves replaced Ricardo Quaresma, but Bayern resumed where they had left off, maintaining their dominance. A brief defensive lapse by FC Porto allowed Mario Gotze a golden opportunity, but his volley sailed just wide of the post.

Bayern’s tactical acumen was on full display as they controlled the tempo with strategic passing and efficient pressing. Xabi Alonso came close from a free-kick, but his shot narrowly missed the crossbar.

The visitors made sporadic attempts to claw back into the game. Ricardo Pereira sent a sumptuous cross into the penalty area, but Bayern's defense stood firm. However, FC Porto finally had something to cheer about in the 72nd minute through Jackson Martinez. A well-directed header into the back of the net from a poised cross marked their first and only goal of the game, making it 5-1.

The joy was short-lived as Bayern Munich continued to threaten. Lewandowski yet again tested FC Porto's goalkeeper, but Fabiano managed a solid save. Bayern's fluid transitions and sharp passing sequences ensured they kept the visitors on the back foot.

The introduction of Mitchell Weiser brought fresh energy into Bayern’s attack. Weiser had an immediate impact, forcing a series of defensive clears from FC Porto. Yet, it was Xabi Alonso who delivered the final blow. A free-kick from 25 meters out, curled beautifully into the left post, left the goalkeeper with no chance. The scoreboard now read an emphatic 6-1, reflecting Bayern’s superior play.

The latter stages saw FC Porto reduced to ten men as Ivan Marcano received his marching orders following a second yellow card for misconduct. Despite being a man down, FC Porto attempted to minimize the damage, but it was Bayern Munich who continued to dominate possession and control the game’s tempo.

The final whistle blew to end a comprehensive and exhilarating performance by Bayern Munich. Their victory was characterized by a blend of tactical discipline, sharp attacking play, and a rock-solid defense. Each goal was a testament to the team’s cohesiveness and their ability to exploit weaknesses in the opposition’s setup. FC Porto, on the other hand, will look back at opportunities missed and an overwhelming struggle to contain Bayern’s relentless assault.

In conclusion, Bayern Munich’s 6-1 triumph over FC Porto was a masterclass in football. The hosts showcased their intent early on and maintained an insurmountable lead, while FC Porto was left to grapple with the ferocity and finesse of Bayern’s gameplay. The home side's ability to maneuver the ball with precision and score from varied plays reiterated their supremacy. On this evidence, Bayern Munich’s march towards greater accolades looks unstoppable.
